title.narrative: Meher Seed Recovery Project in drought affected Woredas of South Wollo Zone

description.narrative: The present project proposal is Seed Recovery intervention and submitted by a cluster comprised of multiple organizations led by FAO. The overall objective of the Project is to improve food security in three Meher growing woredas of Argoba, Borena and Sayint in South Wollo zone in Amhara Region. , where food insecurity is already a serious problem as a result of the erratic Kiremt / Meher rains. The specific objective of the project is emanated from the overall objective and expected to provide seed and increase household food production in 177,235 vulnerable smallholder farmer, reaching 39,063 direct beneficiaries who do not have access to adequate seed and have limited purchasing power to procure seeds. This specific objective is aimed to achieve the outcome of food security of 7,812 drought affected households improved through seed recovery intervention. This means by the end of project period 8517 hectares of land owned by 7,812 farming households planted with seed supplied from the project. GAA\ ORDA shared kebeles in two woredas Borena and Sayint with Goal Ethiopia. This will bring an opportunity for cross fertilization of experiences and enhance to reinforce among projects. Each NOGs are expected to prepare a separate proposal. All agencies will share one logical framework however, each agency would like their own agreement with HRF and will be responsible for their own financial management and follow up of project implementation and monitoring activities. Then beneficiaries’ selection made based on the agreement reached with Goal Ethiopia through the approach of equal division of kebeles. Thus GAA\ORDA took 50% of Borean, Sayint and 100% of Argoba drought affected households. In line with this, the region reviewed its gaps based on the verification assessment outputs. In the crop subsector, the drought victims need replacement seeds to sow in the upcoming meher season. Efforts have been made to fill parts of the needs by the region and NGOs. However, still there are critical gaps to be addressed. This project is designed to address those critical needs through provision of seeds. To track the progress of the project and draw lessons, GAA\ORDA will develop a joint monitoring plan based on the measurable indicators stated in the proposal. The plan will define tools to be used to conduct monitoring, responsible people in the monitoring process, and the frequency and definition of data collection. The monitoring plan will inform and guide project stakeholders to conduct routine monitoring and reporting responsibilities. Based on the cooperative agreement, GAA will report on their respective activities and submit narrative and financial report to HRF/UNOCHA.
